Line 313: Line 313:
{{main|2011 Libyan protests}}
{{main|2011 Libyan protests}}
â
'''January'''
+
The protests also erupted in the country of Libya where enraged dissidents and the government are currently embroiled in titanic violence which has led to the freezing of the assets of Libyaâs leaders including Qaddafi and the withdrawal of oil companies from the country. Angry Demonstrators Call for Libya's Gadaffi to Step Down.<ref>http://news.yahoo.com/s/ac/20110216/pl_ac/7872960_angry_demonstrators_call_for_libyas_gadaffi_to_step_down</ref>
  +
Libya's security forces may yet manage to put down the demonstrations, as they did with a smaller upsurge in 2006, although that is looking increasingly unlikely as the violence spreads and escalates. Eyewitnesses speak of how the Libyan people appear to have lost their fear - and this is a regime more brutal and absolute than the one that was toppled in Egypt earlier this month.<ref>http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23925145-libyan-uprising-risks-red-faces-in-whitehall.do</ref><ref>http://www.hindustantimes.com/Second-wave-of-sandstorm/Article1-665188.aspx</ref>
  +   +
===January===
From 13â16 January, upset at delays and corruption, protesters in [[Darnah, Libya|Darnah]], [[Benghazi]], [[Bani Walid, Libya|Bani Walid]] and other cities in Libya broke into and occupied housing that the government was building.<ref>{{cite web | title = Libyans protest over delayed subsidized housing units | url = http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/libyans-protest-over-delayed-subsidized-housing-units | date = 2011-01-16 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Libya protest over housing enters its third day | url = http://www.mesop.de/2011/01/16/libya-protest-over-housing-enters-its-third-day/ | author = Mohamed Abdel-Baky | date = 2011-01-16 }}</ref> By 27 January the government had responded to the unrest with a $24 billion investment fund to provide housing and development.<ref name=Libya1/>
From 13â16 January, upset at delays and corruption, protesters in [[Darnah, Libya|Darnah]], [[Benghazi]], [[Bani Walid, Libya|Bani Walid]] and other cities in Libya broke into and occupied housing that the government was building.<ref>{{cite web | title = Libyans protest over delayed subsidized housing units | url = http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/libyans-protest-over-delayed-subsidized-housing-units | date = 2011-01-16 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Libya protest over housing enters its third day | url = http://www.mesop.de/2011/01/16/libya-protest-over-housing-enters-its-third-day/ | author = Mohamed Abdel-Baky | date = 2011-01-16 }}</ref> By 27 January the government had responded to the unrest with a $24 billion investment fund to provide housing and development.<ref name=Libya1/>
Line 319: Line 319:
In late January, Jamal al-Hajji, a writer, political commentator and accountant, "call[ed] on the internet for demonstrations to be held in support of greater freedoms in Libya" inspired by the Tunisian and Egyptian uprisings.<ref name="AI_JamalH">{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Libyan writer detained following protest call| work =| publisher =[[Amnesty International]]| date =2011-02-08| url =http://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/libyan-writer-detained-following-protest-call-2011-02-08 |format =| doi =| accessdate =2011-02-08 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wLwGDmVM |archivedate=2011-02-08 |deadurl=no }}</ref> He was arrested on 1 February by plain-clothes police officers and charged on 3 February with injuring someone with his car. [[Amnesty International]] claimed that as al-Hajji had previously been imprisoned for his non-violent political opinions, the real reason for the present arrest appeared to be his call for demonstrations.<ref name="AI_JamalH" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/02/201121755057219793.html |title='Day of rage' kicks off in Libya - Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2006-02-17 |accessdate=2011-02-19}}</ref>
In late January, Jamal al-Hajji, a writer, political commentator and accountant, "call[ed] on the internet for demonstrations to be held in support of greater freedoms in Libya" inspired by the Tunisian and Egyptian uprisings.<ref name="AI_JamalH">{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Libyan writer detained following protest call| work =| publisher =[[Amnesty International]]| date =2011-02-08| url =http://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/libyan-writer-detained-following-protest-call-2011-02-08 |format =| doi =| accessdate =2011-02-08 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wLwGDmVM |archivedate=2011-02-08 |deadurl=no }}</ref> He was arrested on 1 February by plain-clothes police officers and charged on 3 February with injuring someone with his car. [[Amnesty International]] claimed that as al-Hajji had previously been imprisoned for his non-violent political opinions, the real reason for the present arrest appeared to be his call for demonstrations.<ref name="AI_JamalH" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/02/201121755057219793.html |title='Day of rage' kicks off in Libya - Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2006-02-17 |accessdate=2011-02-19}}</ref>
â
'''15 February'''
+
===15 February===
In the late hours of the day between 500 and 600 protesters protested in Benghazi, and clashed with the police, which caused 14 injuries including to 10 police officers.<ref>{{cite news | title = ØªÙØ¬Ø± Ø§Ø´ØªØ¨Ø§ÙØ§Øª ÙÙ ÙØ¯ÙÙØ© Ø¨ÙØºØ§Ø²Ù Ø§ÙÙÙØ¨ÙØ© ÙØ£ÙØ¨Ø§Ø¡ Ø¹Ù Ø§ØµØ§Ø¨Ø© 14 | url = http://ara.reuters.com/article/topNews/idARACAE71F06020110216 | date = 2011-02-16 | work=Reuters}}</ref>
In the late hours of the day between 500 and 600 protesters protested in Benghazi, and clashed with the police, which caused 14 injuries including to 10 police officers.<ref>{{cite news | title = ØªÙØ¬Ø± Ø§Ø´ØªØ¨Ø§ÙØ§Øª ÙÙ ÙØ¯ÙÙØ© Ø¨ÙØºØ§Ø²Ù Ø§ÙÙÙØ¨ÙØ© ÙØ£ÙØ¨Ø§Ø¡ Ø¹Ù Ø§ØµØ§Ø¨Ø© 14 | url = http://ara.reuters.com/article/topNews/idARACAE71F06020110216 | date = 2011-02-16 | work=Reuters}}</ref>
â
'''17 February "Day of Rage"'''
+
===17 February "Day of Rage"===
A "Day of Rage" in Libya and by Libyans in exile was planned for 17 February.<ref name="aljaz_febdominos">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Calls for weekend protests in Syria | date=2011-02-04 | publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201122171649677912.html |accessdate=2011-02-08 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wLygnerq |archivedate=2011-02-08 |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref name="maltatoday_libya_17Feb">{{cite news | first=James | last=Debono | pages= | language =| title=Libyan opposition declares 'Day of Rage' against Gaddafi | date= | publisher=[[Malta Today]] | url=http://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/libyan-opposition-declares-day-of-rage-against-gaddafi |accessdate=2011-02-10 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wP2V8iey |archivedate=2011-02-10 |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref name="awsat" /> The [[National Conference for the Libyan Opposition]] stated that "all" groups opposed to [[Muammar al-Gaddafi]] in Libya and in exile plan protests against Gaddafi on 17 February, in memory of demonstrations in Benghazi on 17 February 2006 that were initially against the [[Timeline of the Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy#17 February|Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons]] and became protests against al-Gaddafi.<ref name="awsat">{{cite news | first=Khaled | last=Mahmoud | pages= | language =| title=Gaddafi ready for Libya's "Day of Rage" | date=2011-02-09 | publisher=[[Asharq al-Awsat]] | url=http://aawsat.com/english/news.asp?section=1&id=24095 |accessdate=2011-02-10 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wP31PQo1 |archivedate=2011-02-10 |deadurl=no }}</ref> The plans to protests are inspired by the revolutions in Tunisia and Egypt.<ref name="awsat" /> In early February, Gaddafi met with "Libyan political activists, journalists, and media figures" and "warned" them that they would be "held responsible" if they participated "in any way in disturbing the peace or creating chaos in Libya".<ref name="awsat" />
A "Day of Rage" in Libya and by Libyans in exile was planned for 17 February.<ref name="aljaz_febdominos">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Calls for weekend protests in Syria | date=2011-02-04 | publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201122171649677912.html |accessdate=2011-02-08 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wLygnerq |archivedate=2011-02-08 |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref name="maltatoday_libya_17Feb">{{cite news | first=James | last=Debono | pages= | language =| title=Libyan opposition declares 'Day of Rage' against Gaddafi | date= | publisher=[[Malta Today]] | url=http://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/libyan-opposition-declares-day-of-rage-against-gaddafi |accessdate=2011-02-10 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wP2V8iey |archivedate=2011-02-10 |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref name="awsat" /> The [[National Conference for the Libyan Opposition]] stated that "all" groups opposed to [[Muammar al-Gaddafi]] in Libya and in exile plan protests against Gaddafi on 17 February, in memory of demonstrations in Benghazi on 17 February 2006 that were initially against the [[Timeline of the Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy#17 February|Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons]] and became protests against al-Gaddafi.<ref name="awsat">{{cite news | first=Khaled | last=Mahmoud | pages= | language =| title=Gaddafi ready for Libya's "Day of Rage" | date=2011-02-09 | publisher=[[Asharq al-Awsat]] | url=http://aawsat.com/english/news.asp?section=1&id=24095 |accessdate=2011-02-10 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wP31PQo1 |archivedate=2011-02-10 |deadurl=no }}</ref> The plans to protests are inspired by the revolutions in Tunisia and Egypt.<ref name="awsat" /> In early February, Gaddafi met with "Libyan political activists, journalists, and media figures" and "warned" them that they would be "held responsible" if they participated "in any way in disturbing the peace or creating chaos in Libya".<ref name="awsat" />
â
'''18 February'''
+
===18 February===
Demonstrations and violent clashes continued to escalate in many Libyan cities, amidst an attempt at a communications and internet blackout by the government. Persistent reports via phone, and social media such as Twitter, asserted that anti-government protesters â with the help of some elements of the security forces â had taken control of the city of [[Benghazi]] and possibly other parts of eastern Libya, seizing at least one radio station. The situation appeared to be fluid, with a potential for massive violence overnight. The loyalties of army and police units on the move within the country were not immediately clear.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/17/live-blog-libya |title=Live Blog - Libya | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.libyafeb17.com/?cat=8 |title=News feed | Libya February 17th |publisher=Libyafeb17.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-19}}</ref><ref>http://twitter.com/search?q=%23Benghazi</ref>
Demonstrations and violent clashes continued to escalate in many Libyan cities, amidst an attempt at a communications and internet blackout by the government. Persistent reports via phone, and social media such as Twitter, asserted that anti-government protesters â with the help of some elements of the security forces â had taken control of the city of [[Benghazi]] and possibly other parts of eastern Libya, seizing at least one radio station. The situation appeared to be fluid, with a potential for massive violence overnight. The loyalties of army and police units on the move within the country were not immediately clear.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/17/live-blog-libya |title=Live Blog - Libya | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.libyafeb17.com/?cat=8 |title=News feed | Libya February 17th |publisher=Libyafeb17.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-19}}</ref><ref>http://twitter.com/search?q=%23Benghazi</ref>
â
'''19 February'''
+
===19 February===
After sharp warnings on state media on the previous day that further protests questioning Libya's political system and leadership would be dealt with harshly, and would be tantamount to "suicide", squads of security forces and â allegedly â mercenaries from sub-Saharan Africa appeared to be following through with a violent campaign to restore order in Eastern Libya. The BBC reported that it had for a time seemed "as if the government had lost control of the eastern cities of al-Badai and Benghazi" and that there was now possibly a sustained battle taking place with government forces over the city of Benghazi.
After sharp warnings on state media on the previous day that further protests questioning Libya's political system and leadership would be dealt with harshly, and would be tantamount to "suicide", squads of security forces and â allegedly â mercenaries from sub-Saharan Africa appeared to be following through with a violent campaign to restore order in Eastern Libya. The BBC reported that it had for a time seemed "as if the government had lost control of the eastern cities of al-Badai and Benghazi" and that there was now possibly a sustained battle taking place with government forces over the city of Benghazi.
Line 341: Line 341:
Amidst a continuing communications blackout, late in the day unconfirmed but persistent reports emerged describing clashes with demonstrators and troops firing live ammunition in Tripoli, where the government has enjoyed much greater popularity.<ref>http://twitter.com/search?q=%23Tripoli</ref> The residents of Bengazi told Al Jazeera that at least 200 people had died while the [[New York]] based [[Human Rights Watch]] put the countrywide death toll at a "conservative" 104 on February 19.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/02/20112206386812127.html |title=Libya unrest death toll 'tops 200' - Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-21}}</ref>
Amidst a continuing communications blackout, late in the day unconfirmed but persistent reports emerged describing clashes with demonstrators and troops firing live ammunition in Tripoli, where the government has enjoyed much greater popularity.<ref>http://twitter.com/search?q=%23Tripoli</ref> The residents of Bengazi told Al Jazeera that at least 200 people had died while the [[New York]] based [[Human Rights Watch]] put the countrywide death toll at a "conservative" 104 on February 19.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/02/20112206386812127.html |title=Libya unrest death toll 'tops 200' - Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-21}}</ref>
â
'''20 February'''
+
===20 February===
Al Jazeera reported anti-government demonstrations numbering in the thousands in the Libyan capital of Tripoli for the first time. Demonstrators were fired on by government forces. Reports described mobs destroying the cars of pro-government patrols, and protesters arming themselves with makeshift weapons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/17/live-blog-libya |title=Live Blog - Libya | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=2011-02-17 |accessdate=2011-02-21}}</ref>
Al Jazeera reported anti-government demonstrations numbering in the thousands in the Libyan capital of Tripoli for the first time. Demonstrators were fired on by government forces. Reports described mobs destroying the cars of pro-government patrols, and protesters arming themselves with makeshift weapons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/17/live-blog-libya |title=Live Blog - Libya | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=2011-02-17 |accessdate=2011-02-21}}</ref>
Line 353: Line 353:
As an alternative, he offered, within 48 hours, to call a conference to set up a new constitution with "new media laws, civil rights, lift the stupid punishments, we will have a constitution. Even the Leader Gaddafi said he wants a constitution. We can even have autonomous rule, with limited central govt powers." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/acarvin |title=Andy Carvin (acarvin) on Twitter |publisher=Twitter.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Time |url=http://www.tweetdeck.com/twitter/exiledsurfer/~oJiWX |title=exiledsurfer: "Full text of Saif ..." Â« Deck.ly |publisher=Tweetdeck.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-21}}</ref>
As an alternative, he offered, within 48 hours, to call a conference to set up a new constitution with "new media laws, civil rights, lift the stupid punishments, we will have a constitution. Even the Leader Gaddafi said he wants a constitution. We can even have autonomous rule, with limited central govt powers." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/acarvin |title=Andy Carvin (acarvin) on Twitter |publisher=Twitter.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Time |url=http://www.tweetdeck.com/twitter/exiledsurfer/~oJiWX |title=exiledsurfer: "Full text of Saif ..." Â« Deck.ly |publisher=Tweetdeck.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-21}}</ref>
â
'''21 February'''
+
===21 February===
Immediately following Saif's speech, large crowds of protesters who had marched to Tripoli's Green Square were attacked by many armed men in cars. Large numbers were killed and injured, worsening the medical and humanitarian crisis facing the city as Tripoli fell into chaos. Overnight, furious crowds ransacked and burned many government buildings.
Immediately following Saif's speech, large crowds of protesters who had marched to Tripoli's Green Square were attacked by many armed men in cars. Large numbers were killed and injured, worsening the medical and humanitarian crisis facing the city as Tripoli fell into chaos. Overnight, furious crowds ransacked and burned many government buildings.
